page.p: "J. R. Firth (1957) introduced the term ‘collocations’ for characteristic and frequently recurrent word combinations, arguing that the meaning and usage of a word (the node) can to some extent be characterized by its most typical collocates [...]" (Evert 2009: 1212f., emphasis added)

details.p: "A node is an item whose total pattern of co-occurrence with other words is under examination; a collocate is any one of the items which appears with the node within a specified span. Essentially there is no difference in status between node and collocate; if word A is a node and word B one of its collocates, when word B is studied as a node, word A will become one of its collocates." (Sinclair, 2004, cited in McEnery/Hardie 2012: 124)

page.p: Much-cited, in this regard, is Firth’s sentence "You shall know a word by the company it keeps" ( Firth 1957, cited in Evert 2009: 1213, emphasis added).

details.p: This quotation is reminiscent of Wittgenstein and his theory of meaning as use. (cf. Lemnitzer/Zinsmeister 2010:30)

page.p: According to Firth, examples of collocations would be "day" and "night" or "cow" and "milk".
Regarding collocations he gives priority to the mutual expectancy between words and, thus, to the influence of statistics.

Firth'sdefinition remains a fairly vague starting point. As a consequence, nowadays collocations are interpreted variously in the fields of computational linguistics, phraseology, foreign language didactics and, last but not least, in corpus linguistics.

according to Hausmann (2004), a collocation is understood as a binary structure consisting of the two units base and collocate. He elaborates that it is a phraseological combination of two words bearing a hierarchical relationship of dependence. Especially the last aspect becomes clearer with Hausmann's examples, saying that a noun like "experience" does not need the verb "undergo" for its existence. However, the collocate "undergo" urgently requires a base to be anything at all: "undergo tests", "undergo repairs", "undergo medical treatment". (cf.Hausmann 1991: 231).

In other words: "In a collocation, the collocate is lexically selected by the base (Hausmann, 1985). The base can be interpreted outside the context of the collocation [...], whereas the interpretation of the collocate is contingent upon the specific collocation [...] (Hausmann, 2004)" (Seretan2011: 24).
According to Hausmann(1991), other examples of collocates are "(to) meet the deadline" or "confirmed bachelor".

details.p: In sum, for Hausmann collocations are two-part word combinations which are showing a hierarchy and a dependency relation.

"In the current literature, collocations are seen as expressions that ‘fall somewhere along a continuum between free word combinations and idioms’" (McKeown and Radev, 2000, cited in Seretan2011: 23).

page.p: As well in the fields of lexicography and foreign language didactics one orientates oneself by Hausmann'sconcept of collocations..

details.p: In his opinion there is a terminological war going on for reclaiming the term "collocation". The coexistence of different definitions he considers a historically grown perversion within the scientific discourse. (cf. Hausmann 2004: 320f.).

page.p: collocations are lexicalised word combinations with semantic or syntactic properties. They are non-compositionaland their components are non-modifiable and non-substitutable.

details.p: Non-compositional means that the meaning of the collocation cannot be deduced from the meanings of its components.
Non-modifiable means that a collocate cannot be freely extended or grammatically transformed. For example, you cannot say "pull my legs" but "pull my leg".
Non-substitutable means that the components of a collocation cannot be substituted, not even by near-synonyms (e.g. "hold a talk" instead of "give a talk").

page.p: According to this definition, collocations are presenting a challenge for natural language processing in general and in particular, for example, for the field of machine translation since collocations cannot be translated word by word into the target language.
Recently, collocation has been superseded by the more neutral term multiword expression in computational linguistics.
Examples of collocations in computational linguistics are "kick the bucket" or "stiff drink".
collocations are mostly interpreted in the tradition of Firth as two words which occur more often together than by random chance.

details.p: Thus, if one can find "[...] mathematical evidence [by using statistical methods] that the co-occurrence pattern is unlikely to be due to chance [...]" (McEnery/Hardie2012: 125) and that the combination of two words occurs "[...] more often than the frequencies in the corpus of the constituents of the combination would lead us to expect" (Kjellmer cited in : 112) then we are talking about collocations, even if the combination is not corresponding to Hausmann’s ideas of being well-formed or meaningful.

page.p: In order to clearly distinguish it from the phraseological definition some scientists like Evert (2009) or Biemann/Bordag/Quasthoff (2003) expand the term and differentiate between empirical and theoretical or statistical and linguistic collocations.
Examples of such empirical or statistical collocations would be "although he" or "public gaze".
Another way out of the dilemma is for example Belicapursuing. He only refers to co-occurrences which are consistent with Hausmann's dichotomy of base and collocate as collocations.
As for Scherer(2006), co-occurrences are a synonym for collocations being words which are disproportionally often occurring in proximity to one another.

Perkuhn/Keibel/Kupietz (2012) prefer the term co-occurrence because of the problems resulting from Firth's and Hausmann's divergent definitions of the term collocation. However, they emphasize that they are not concerned with the mere co-occurrence of two words, as the literal meaning of the term would suggest. Essential aspects for them are rather the recurrence as well as the statistical evaluation of the combination.

On the other hand, Steyer (2004) defines a co-occurrence as quality of cohesion determined by mathematical-statistical calculations. If the words being part of the statistically striking combination are furthermore hierarchically linked to each other and if they are meeting Hausmann's definition, they can also be described as collocations.

details.p: According to Steyer and Belica, the contextual combination of the words "water" and "air" would for example be a co-occurrence if a strong and remarkable cohesion could be proven using mathematical-statistical calculations. The word pair "clean" and "water" is additionally meeting Hausmann's definition and represents therefore a collocation.

page.h2: Then there is the colligation as well...
page.p: The term colligation cannot be found very often in secondary literature on corpus linguistics, but at least it is used uniformly. Unlike the lexical or content level of collocations, the focus of colligations is on the structure and hence on grammar. Attention here is drawn to the grammatical relationship between word pairs. "For instance, many words colligate with the word the, which is a grammatical marker of definiteness rather than a word that carries significant semantic content. Colligation with the is in fact typical of many words traditionally described as nouns." (McEnery/Hardie2012: 130)
Another example of a colligation is "have made".

question.ctext: 1. I am able to establish a connection between the term collocation and the name J.R. Firth and to give some keywords in this respect.

ctext.p: J. R. Firth introduced the term collocation and is therefore often mentioned in this context. Well-known is his sentence "You shall know a word by the company it keeps", because in his opinion collocations give some indication of the node's meaning and of how it is used. With reference to collocations, Firth speaks of frequently recurring word combinations and mutual expectancy.

question.ctext: 2. I am capable of roughly outlining the readings of collocation in phraseology, computational linguistics and corpus linguistics.

ctext.p: In phraseology one follows Hausmann’s definition according to which collocations consist of a base and a collocate. They constitute a combination of two interdependent, hierarchically related words.

In computational linguistics collocations are understood as lexicalised word combinations with semantic or syntactic properties presenting a challenge for natural language processing. Instead of collocations the term multiword expressions is used with increasing frequency, though.

In corpus linguistics what is meant by "(empirical/statistical) collocation" is the combination of two words which tend to occur near each other. This co-occurrence is unlikely to be due to chance but rather significant.

question.ctext: 3.I am aware of the terminological problem regarding the terms collocation and co-occurrence.

action.ctext: A co-occurrence can be defined as the mere co-occurrence of two words or as a precursor or even a synonym for collocation. Collocations on the other hand can be construed as general term for linguistic challenges in computational linguistics. Furthermore, Hausmann defines collocations from a phraseological viewpoint and, on the basis of statistics, they are interpreted as two words which occur more often in proximity to one another than by random chance. The two terms are not clearly definable or separated from each other.

page.p: In view of the above it should have become clear that both the term collocation and the term co-occurrence show certain problems, whereas colligations are barely mentioned.

In corpus linguistics the focus is on the co-occurrence of words. Nevertheless, it is not the mere co-occurrence which is of interest, but the question whether there exists any attraction between the words and whether the joint appearance is more frequent than by random chance, if not even significant. In this respect, it should be pointed out that the words do not have to occur immediately adjacently. Usually, analysis is based on a span of five words each side of the node.

details.p: Apart from that, however, approaches exist which look at significant co-occurrences of two words within the same textual unit (e.g. within a sentence or utterance). "This is particularly counterintuitive for languages with relatively free word order, where closely related words can be far apart on the surface." (Evert 2009: 1222) Another approach only considers words as co-occurrence if they are syntactically related in a direct or indirect way. Hence, the objects of study are colligations. (cf. Evert 2009: 1222f.)

page.p: Thus, in comparison to co-occurrences the important criterion of statistics is added. This distinction shall be expressed by subsequently using the term collocation in the tradition of Firth . Admittedly, as a consequence there is an ambiguity present as regards the terminology of Hausmann, but the aspects of hierarchic determination etc. won’t be taken into account.

details.p: Summarized this means: When two words are displayed as significant by applying mathematical-statistical methods, we will call the word pair a collocation, regardless of whether the combination is grammatically correct or meaningful.

question.ctext: 1.I have understood the terminology this module is based on.

action.ctext: Within this module preference will be given to the term collocation meaning combinations or word pairs which are co-occurring more frequently than by random chance and which are therefore significant. Mathematical-statistical calculations play an important role in this, while the aspects of being well-formed and hierarchical determined, which are important for Hausmann, are not taken into account.

page.p: By means of a collocation analysis – sometimes also referred to as co-occurrence analysis in secondary literature – the most significant collocates of a chosen node are identified by applying statistical methods. For this purpose, parameters have to be set and a significance measure has to be chosen.

details.p: They form the basis of the calculations and can reflect different perspectives on the corpus. That is why they should be adapted to the respective research question or objective.

page.p: As a result of the collocation analysis, the collocation profile of the node will be displayed.
page.img: Collocation profile of the word form "people" / Image source: Corpus "U.S. Presidents Inaugural Speeches": powered by CQPweb

page.p: The collocation profile of a word is the total of its relevant collocations. While a single collocation illustrates only a partial area, a collocation profile represents many, if not all, important aspects of how a word is used. Thereby we can get an overview of all the discourses in which the maybe differing meanings of a word were constituted. (cf. Perkuhn/Keibel/Kupietz 2012: 127).

Basically, collocations have a binary structure: As a result of a collocation analysis, generally the most significant primary collocates of a node are listed. It is possible to expand this structure. In a second step you could additionally calculate the most significant collocates of a primary collocate and in so doing you would obtain the secondary collocates.
There exist two possible approaches:

list.li: The computation of collocates in the contexts of the respective collocation. For example: "America" + "freedom" are a collocation. Another collocate like "ideal" is a secondary collocate in contexts, where the collocation "America" + "freedom" occurs. An example of this is the cooccurrence analysis of Belica.
On the other hand, the secondary collocate can also be calculated from all the contexts of the primary collocate.

question.ctext: 1. I am capable of explaining what is meant by the terms collocation analysis and collocation profile.

ctext.p: When performing a collocation analysis, the most significant collocates of a node are calculated on the basis of the selected parameters and association measure using statistical methods.
The collocation profile of a word is the total of its relevant collocations and hence reflects how a word is used.

page.h2: What is the purpose of calculating collocations?
page.p: A collocation analysis can serve

list.li: as an indication of the order or hierarchy of the readings of a linguistic sign in a dictionary article.
→ What are the most common meanings of the lexeme?
to identify, verify or describe typical word combinations, idioms or phraseologisms.
→ Which collocations are used?
→ Which collocations are particularly common and which are hard to find or not to be found at all?
→ What is their meaning and in which context are they used?
to detect common grammatical patterns.
to reveal syntactic structures
e.g. phrasal verbs
to illustrate the semantic fields of a word.
to identify thematic areas.
to compare the manners of use and the meanings of a node's word forms.
e.g. comparing the singular and plural form of the node
to highlight how certain terms are used in a discourse
"[...] to argue for the importance of certain words as diagnostics of cultural attitudes [...]" (Stubbs, 1996, cited in Hunston2002: 76)
Collocations can be analyzed as reflecting traditions of phrasing and conventions of language use.

page.p: Hence, collocation analyses are also of importance for the fields of lexicography and lexicology, foreign language didactics, translation studies and discourse linguistics.

list.li: cf. Heyer/Quasthoff/Wittig 2008: 154f.
cf. Hunston 2002: 76f.
cf. Lemnitzer/Zinsmeister 2010: 144f.

page.p: Combining Critical Discourse Analysis (CDA) with corpus linguistic methodology, Debbie Orpin (2005) undertook a study of 8 nouns semantically related to corruption. By means of the concordancer and collocational software tools, she examined the semantic profiles and connotational differences of these words. Furthermore, she intended to test the hypothesis "[...] that words with a noticeably negative connotation tend to be used when referring to activities that take place outside of Britain, while less negative words are used when referring to similar activities in British contexts." (38)

As data basis she chose the Bank of English corpus which contains texts dated from 1990 - 1996, amounting to 323 million words, whereas she limited the detailed study to four sub-corpora representing data from British newspapers. In a next step Debbie Orpin selected a set of nouns being synonyms, near-synonyms, or hyponyms of corruptionkursiv>. For this purpose she consulted two thesauri and sifted through the most significant collocates of corruptionkursiv> in the Bank of English corpus. If the selected nouns also occurred at least 15 times in the four sub-corpora they qualified for the final set, including bribery, corruption, cronyism, graft, impropriety/ies, malpractice(s), nepotism and sleaze.

After creating a basis for analysis, the researcher calculated the most significant collocates of each item within a span of four words to the left and to the right of the node, using the association measure t-score. "Since graft is polysemous, all concordances relating to senses other than the "corruption" sense were eliminated before the collocation program was run." (42)

In general, the resulting list showed that corruption is a collocate of each noun except impropriety and that there are several more shared collocates, which is no surprise given the fact that the items were chosen because of their semantic overlap. However, there are also unique collocates, which "[...] are likely to highlight differences in areas of activity, people or places with which each word is associated and may also highlight differences in the attitude encoded by the user of the item to what is being spoken of." (49)

Hence, while all nouns show connections with politics, public office and officialdom, the field of sport is represented by bribery (e.g. cricket), nepotism and sleaze (both football) and malpractice is linked with finance, law and medicine (costs, doctors, legal).

Regarding geographical locations, the most significant collocate of bribery is Pakistan, corruption and impropriety are for example used in the context of Australia (Fitzgerald, Cranston) and neopotism as well as sleaze bear reference to Britain.

At last the connotations of the nouns were analyzed, finding out that all items except sleaze, cronyism and impropriety are for example linked with criminal activities. Sleaze and corruption also collocate with greed, and sleaze and impropriety are moreover associated with sex. Generally speaking: "The semantic profiles of the words bribery, corruption, graft and nepotism appear to have particularly negative connotations. All are associated with criminal activities, and corruption, graft and nepotism also have collocates which indicate a particularly negative speaker attitude." (53) On the other hand, malpractice, impropriety and sleaze have the least negative connotations.

Summing up, it can be said that Orpin was able to analyze a large amount of data by using corpus methodology, which "[...] made it possible to identify the different shades of meaning among the members of a set of closely related words, and helped to highlight areas of semantic overlap and areas of divergence." (59)

question.ctext: 1.I am able to name two fields in which collocation analyses are applied and to give examples of their purpose.

ctext.p: Collocation analyses are used in the fields of lexicography and lexicology, foreign language didactics, translation studies and discourse linguistics among others.

By means of this procedure, conventions of language use, semantic fields and grammatical structures can for example be revealed. When writing a dictionary article it gives some indication of the order of readings and provides examples of how the word is commonly used.

action.url: What is the purpose of calculating collocations?

page.p: Statistical calculations play a major role in collocation analyses. In order to be able to set the analysis parameters and to interpret the results correctly you should acquire a basic knowledge in this area. The previous statements on collocations have already included mathematical-statistical terms like more frequent than chance or significant. First of all it will be clarified what precisely is understood by these terms:

If you would arrange the words in a corpus completely randomly, word a and word bwould co-occur x times due to chance. If a word combination is the product of random chance, the two words are independent of each other. This is also called the null hypothesis. However, if the two words co-occur more often than x, this co-occurrence is more frequent than chance.

details.p: "Words are never combined at random in natural language, being subject to a variety of syntactic, semantic and lexical restrictions." (Evert2009: 1244) Hence, the null hypothesis, which says that word a and word b are independent of and not at all attracted to each other, is controversial.

page.p: Think back to your mathematics lessons:

At the beginning, probability calculation is often explained with the help of a dice. We will use the simpler example of a coin: When flipping a coin ten times, one could expect to see five times heads and five times tails. If the coin shows six or seven times heads this can still be a coincidence. Nevertheless, the outcome exceeds our expectation of an even distribution and is therefore more frequent than chance.

Sticking to the example mentioned before: If you see nine or even ten times heads, when flipping a coin ten times, it is more than improbable that this is just a coincidence. The deviation from what we expected is so high, that it can be called significant.

When interpreting collocations which occur more often than chance, statements about the underlying corpus can be derived. If the collocations are significant, though, one can draw general conclusions. Despite all this, statistical calculations based on probabilities are fallible.

Hence, when calculating frequency and significance it needs to be determined how often a word or a word combination occurs and how often we would have expected this occurrence. As a consequence, the observed and the expected frequencies are relevant for a collocation analysis.:
The so-called Observed Frequency (O) is simply the number of actual occurrences of a word combination in a corpus.
It is particularly insightful when considering the size of the corpus.

details.p: It stands to reason that a word combination with O = 5 in a corpus consisting of 30 words seems more considerable than in a corpus of size N=100.

page.p: The observed frequency as well as the actual occurrences of node, collocate and of the other words in the corpus are required in order to calculate the significance of a collocation.
The necessary values are obtained by counting:

list.li: how often word₁ and word₂ are co-occurring (within a previously specified span),
b) how often only word₁ occurrs,
c) how often word₂ occurs by itself and
d) how often neither word₁ nor word₂ occur, meaning how many words are neither word₁ nor word₂.

page.p: It can be helpful to enter these items in a so-called contingency table.

details.p: In statistics "contingency" means: "[...]the degree of association between theoretical and observed common frequencies of two graded or classified variables." (Collins Dictionary online, "contingency")

page.p: In order to be able to exclude the possibility of a random distribution of the words, not only the actual occurrences but also the expected frequencies play a major role.
In order to determine whether the words are evenly or randomly distributed in a corpus or not, you consider the so-called expected frequency (E).

details.p: "E is important as a reference point for the interpretation of O, since two frequent words might cooccur quite often purely by chance." (Evert2009: 1228)

page.p: For calculating the expected frequency of a word combination, you set the single frequencies of the collocates in relation to the overall size of the corpus. So first of all you count the occurrence (f₁) of word a and the occurrence (f₂) of word b. Then, in relation to the total (N) of word tokens in the corpus, the Expected Frequency (E) is calculated as follows:
E = f₁ ∙ f₂⁄N

details.p: Evert explains this in more detail using the example of the collocation is to which occurs 260 times in the Brown corpus. The component is occurs approximately 10,000 while to has a frequency of about 26,000 times among 1 million word tokens. If the words were distributed randomly, the word pair would be expected to co-occur roughly 260 times. Because this number reflects the actual occurrence, is to is not regarded as significant, though.

"The expected number of cooccurrences for a completely ‘uncollocational’ word pair has been derived by the following reasoning: to occurs 26 times every 1,000 words on average. If there is no association between is and to, then each of the 10,000 instances of is in the Brown corpus has a chance of 26/1,000 to be followed by to. Therefore, we expect around 10,000 X (26/1,000) = 260 occurrences of the bigram is to, provided that there is indeed no association between the words." ( Evert2009: 1225)

page.p: Basically, collocations are considered significant if the observed frequency (O) clearly exceeds the expected frequency (E) while always factoring in a certain tolerance range.

Most significance or association measures, however, are not only taking into account (O) and (E) of the collocation but also include in the calculation the observed and expected frequency for each of the four items described above.
Therefore it seems reasonable to compile a contingency table of the expected frequencies in a second step, too.

The contingency tables of the observed and the expected frequencies provide all the values which are required for a so-called significance test.

If words co-occur repeatedly this suggests that there is some attraction or cohesion between them. The strength of this attraction or the level of cohesion can be calculated using significance measures.
As the name implies, significance measures give information on the significance of collocations and thus evaluate them statistically in terms of their conspicuousness.

Thereby also those word pairs come to your attention which might not be very frequent but whose combination is striking in some way, meaning that there is an association between the words, because a surprisingly large part (beyond chance) of the overall occurrences of one component was observed in proximity to the other one. (cf. Perkuhn/Keibel/Kupietz 2012: 114)

details.p: "Mere recurrence is not a sufficient indicator for a strong attraction between words [...]. [...] By interpreting occurrences of words as events, statistical association measures can be used to quantify the attraction between coocurring words." (Evert2009: 1215) In this way it is also possible to exclude word pairs whose recurrence might be a purely random effect. So basically the issue is highlighted of how unlikely it is that two words co-occur purely by chance and that there is no association at all between them.

page.p: At this point two significance measures will be described briefly.

Basically, the chi-square test or also χ²test measures the difference between the observed and the expected frequencies, including all the values of the previously created contingency tables. So for each cell (O - E)²⁄E needs to be calculated and the respective results are then added.
This results in the formula χ² = ∑ (O - E)²⁄E

"The essence of the test is to compare the observed frequencies in the table with the frequencies expected for independence. If the difference between observed and expected frequencies is large, then we can reject the null hypothesis of independence." (Manning/Schütze 2003: 168)

In order to find out whether the value calculated in this way is significant, the table of critical values of χ² has to be consulted. Looking up the distribution for a fourfold contingency table it shows that χ² needs to be greater than 3.84 in order that the probability of the null hypothesis is only 5% (p = 0.05). If χ² exceeds the critical value of 6.64, then the null hypothesis can be rejected at a probability level of 99% (p = 0.01) and if χ²is even greater than 10.83 it is 99.9% certain (p = 0.001) that the collocation does not occur due to chance alone and that the co-occurrence is significant.
Applying the chi-square test is problematic in cases where the contingency tables contain very small numbers. If the values are less than E = 5 the results are no longer reliable.

In contrast to χ² the log-likelihood test is more robust against low values of E and hence provides better results for sparse data. The log-likelihood ratio is the most appropriate for discovering collocations and the most common significance measure in corpus linguistics. Provided that it is an available option, it should therefore be given preference to this measure.
The formula for calculating the LLR is:
G² = 2[A log A + Blog B + C log C + D log D
- (A+B) log(A+B) - (A+C) log(A+C)
- (B+D) log(B+D) - (C+D) log(C+D)
+ (A+B+C+D) log(A+B+C+D)]
In order to determine whether the resulting values are significant, one can draw on the critical values of χ² once more.

Regarding significance measures you should generally keep in mind that individual values may not necessarily be revealing. If for example the collocation "National Government" scores a LLR of 44,309 it is indeed highly significant, nevertheless the word combination "Federal Government" resulting in a LLR of 259,647 shows an even greater cohesion.

Furthermore you must consider the weak point of significance measures which is that, "[...] if O is sufficiently large, even a small relative difference between O and E [...] can be highly significant [...]." (Evert2009: 1228)

Hence, also Manning/Schütze state: "[...] [S]tatistical tests are most useful as a method for ranking collocations. The level of significance itself is less useful. In fact, in most publications that we cite in this chapter, the level of significance is never looked at. All that is used is the scores and the resulting ranking." (2003: 166)

When using corpus analysis software, the chosen significance measure is thankfully calculated automatically. Usually collocations are listed in descending order sorted by significance or frequency according to the selected parameters. Since high scores indicate a strong attraction the data can be interpreted intuitively.

question.ctext: I am capable of distinguishing between the terms significant and frequent.

ctext.p: 1. A frequent collocation is a word combination which occurs often in a corpus. Its occurrence is counted in comparison to other collocations.

In order to be able to rate a collocation’s significance, the total size of the corpus is also taken into account. It will then be calculated how often a word combination would be expected if the words were distributed evenly.

question.ctext: 2. I have the ability to describe the observed and the expected frequency.

ctext.p: By the observed frequency the actual occurrence of a collocation is meant. The expected frequency is calculated by multiplying the single frequencies of collocate and node and dividing the result by the total size of the corpus. That way the values of a random distribution are determined. If they are clearly exceeded, the word combination is significant.

question.ctext: 3. I am able to specify the four values, which are required for significance tests.

list.li: how often word₁ and word₂ are co-occurring (within a previously defined span),
how often only word₁ occurs,
how often word₂ occurs by itself,
how many words are neither word1₁ nor word₂.

ctext.p: It is necessary to determine the observed frequency as well as the expected frequency for all of the four values.

question.ctext: I comprehended the purpose of significance measures and I can name two.

ctext.p: Significance measures evaluate collocations statistically in terms of their conspicuousness and they express the strength of attraction or the level of cohesion between two words. By means of significance tests, the possibility of the co-occurrence being a random effect can be ruled out. At the same time, attention may be drawn to word combinations which might not be very frequent but whose combination might be significant. It should be considered as well that individual values are not necessarily revealing. Usually the collocates are ranked according to their association scores.
The most common significance measure in corpus linguistics is the log-likelihood ratio. Moreover, chi-square, MI or t-score are applied.

page.h1: Possible reasons for the association between words
page.p: If two words tend to co-occur it is likely that there is some kind of connection in terms of function or content between them. A strong attraction between node and collocate may have various reasons but is mostly due to a paradigmatic or statistical-syntagmatic relation.
Possible reasons contributing to a high level of cohesion are:

list.li: Dependencies (e.g. John works)
The collocation forms a compound noun (e.g. orange juice).
The collocation forms (part of) a multi-word proper name (e.g. New York)
The collocate is a superordinate or subordinate term of the node.
The collocate is a synonym or antonym of the node.
Collocate and node are part of a listing.
The collocation is (part of) an idiom or phrase.
There exists a cause-effect relationship between collocate and node (e.g. flooding and rainfall).
The collocate or the node serves as an aid or tool (e.g. microscope and magnification).
There is a part-whole relationship present (e.g. page and book).
The collocate or node terms an agent or objects of an action (e.g. assassin and kills or beer and drink).
The collocate or node describes typical properties (e.g. warm with water).
The collocate or node is a measurement of a substance (e.g. tonne and grain).

page.p: Moreover, collocations can reflect semantic compatibility, cultural stereotypes or institutionalised phrases or simply describe a real-world situation.
The reasons listed here might likewise serve as basis for or aid to interpretation.
(cf. Evert 2009: 1218f.; Heyer/Quasthoff/Wittig 2008: 24-38, 148f.)

page.p: The parameters a collocation analysis is based on can be varied according to the research question or hypothesis. At the same time they offer the possibility to look at the object of study from different perspectives. You should always bear in mind that the choice of parameters also directs the researcher’s focus and decisively affects the results of the analysis.

details.p: Evert summarizes it as follows: "The resulting set or ranking of collocations depends on many parameters, including the size and composition of the corpus, [...], application of frequency thresholds, the definition of cooccurrence used, and the choice of association measure. It is up to the researcher to find a suitable and meaningful combination of parameters, or to draw on results from multiple parameter settings in order to highlight different aspects of collocativity." (Evert 2009: 1243)

page.p: Without any doubt it is challenging that one has to speculate on the nature of the phenomenon already when deciding on the respective parameters. Adopting a data-driven approach you would therefore, as the name implies, draw guidance to a certain extent from the results. If necessary you would readjust the parameters.
Furthermore, a collocation analysis may give impetus to phrasing research questions or hypotheses which might only emerge in the course of the analysis.
The adjustable parameters of a collocation analysis usually include:

Collocations do not necessarily have to consist of two words which are immediately adjacent but they can also be discontinuous. Hence, when carrying out a collocation analysis you usually specify beforehand the co- or context which shall be included. According to Perkuhn/Keibel/Kupietz , a span of five words to the right and five words to the left of the node is often considered to be the most telling context. Again, the research question is decisive, because asymmetric or very narrow collocational spans may also be appropriate.

details.p: As an example, if you examine the question which adjectives are significantly combined with a specific noun, it seems reasonable to select a left-sided span because of the English word order.

page.p: The results of an analysis are shown in the following way: If a collocate occurs as left neighbor of the node, the position is marked with a "-". -4 would therefore mean that the collocate (e.g. water) occupies the fourth position before the node (e.g. drink).
Example: "She stopped at the water fountain for a drink."

The positions to the right of the node word are represented with positive numbers, which might additionally be preceded with a "+". So if a collocate is for example the adjacent neighbor on the right side of the node, its position would be 1 or +1.
Depending on the software which is used, it may be possible to display which positions a collocate occupies how often.

Regarding the window span, the punctuation needs to be considered as well: Can we still refer to a word combination as collocation when the two words do not occur in the same sentence? Normally, sentence boundaries within the specified span are disregarded, which means that collocations are calculated across sentence boundaries. However, this might be adjusted, depending on the software.

"Span size is the most important choice that has to be made by the researcher [...]" (1221, emphasis added), according to Evert (2009). At the same time, this arbitrariness is considered a point of criticism, though.

details.p: For a span size of 3, throw a birthday party would be accepted as a coocurrence of (throw, party), but throw a huge birthday party would not.(Evert 2009: 1222)

page.p: The difficulty here is that you do not know before which position the collocate prefers. That is why the results should be assessed critically and the parameters might have to be readjusted.

Another parameter which can or must be set in advance when performing a collocation analysis is the minimum frequency of the collocation as well as of the node and the potential collocate. Hence, one can or must decide how often a word combination or the respective words have to occur in the corpus to be included in the calculation.

According to Evert (2009), one should keep in mind that "[i]t is not uncommon to find more than a million recurrent word pairs (f ≥ 2) in a corpus containing several hundred million running words, but only a small proportion of them [words] will pass a frequency threshold of f ≥ 10 or higher, as a consequence of Zipf’s law [...]" (Evert 2009: 1215). (cf. remarks on Zipf’s law in the module "Concordances and Keyword Lists")

He goes on to say that the parameter "minimum frequency" can also be set as a threshold to exclude infrequent recurrent word pairs or mere co-occurrences from the calculation beforehand. Besides, when the list of the most significant collocates is finally displayed, one could distinguish between "strong" and "weak" collocations in a next step by defining a certain significance value as threshold again.

However, it is more practicable not to apply an arbitrary threshold but to have a closer look at the top 50 or 100 collocates of the ranked list. Because, as already explained in the section on significance measures, the scores are less decisive than the ranking obtained by comparing them.

So, one should always analyze the collocations showing the highest significance or strongest attraction. Nonetheless, given the already mentioned weak point of significance measures, selecting a minimum frequency or frequency threshold might be useful after all:

"[...] accidental cooccurrences between low-frequency words may achieve very high association scores. An extensive study of this effect has resulted in the recommendation to apply a frequency threshold of f ≥ 5 in order to weed out potentially spurious collocations [...]" (Evert 2009: 1244).

As already explained, there exist different association measures which are of varying importance in corpus linguistics and which are based on different calculations. As is mostly the case you can choose between LLR, Chi-Quadrat, T-Score, Z-Score and Mutual Information (MI) when carrying out a collocation analysis. Often the results can also be ranked by frequency.
"Different measures highlight different aspects of collocativity and will hence be more or less appropriate for different tasks [...]" (Evert 2009: 1236, emphasis added)
Despite this range it is commonly advisable to choose the log-likelihood ratio as significance measure.
Further literature on the subject of association measures:

page.p: Usually, when performing a collocation analysis one can decide whether the calculation of the most significant collocates is based on the lemmata, the word forms or the parts of speech (POS).

If you choose lemma as basis, the infinitive of a word and its inflected forms are pooled for the calculations. So when the analysis is carried out, the infinitive and the word forms are treated as a package so to say and in the collocation profile they are listed under the lemma. For example, one of the resulting most significant collocates might be the lemma "say". When looking into the hits you would also find the word forms "said", "says" or the like.

If the collocation analysis shall be based on the word form, the inflected forms of a word are treated as individual collocates. Hence, the frequency and significance not only of the word "say" will be calculated but also of the words "says", "said" etc. As a result, all the word forms are then listed in the collocation profile sorted by their respective association scores.

A third option is to take the POS, in other words the parts of speech, as a basis of collocation analyses. For the calculations the collocates of a node are then pooled according to the parts of speech they are representing. In the collocation profile you will find abbreviations or more precisely tags, which are usually aligned with the Penn Treebank TagSet. In consequence, one may read for example RB (Adverb) or VBD (Verb, past tense) among the results and thus you would learn that the node is forming a significant collocation with adverbs or past tense verbs.

Furthermore it is possible to filter the calculated collocations by parts of speech. For this purpose there is a drop down list available in some tools from which you can choose of annotated parts of speech by means of the just mentioned tags. This way, one can display for example a list of modal verbs (MD) or personal pronouns (PP) being collocates of the node, sorted in descending order by significance or frequency. It allows for another perspective and a more targeted search.
Penn Treebank TagSet
For more detail see: Penn Treebank TagSet

Depending on the software which is used for calculating and analyzing collocations, it may be possible to include or exclude function words. Those are words which express grammatical relationships but have no or little meaning, like articles or conjunctions.
Hence, when excluding function words or synsemantic words from the collocation analysis, only words which carry meaning, like nouns and verbs are shown.

As usual, the choice of parameters depends on the research question. If one wants to look for example at syntactic aspects (and is e.g. interested in phrasal verbs or partitives), certainly function words are rather of importance than for questions regarding topic or content (like the question of typical contexts in which a node is used).

question.ctext: 1. It has become clear to me why the parameters are crucial to a collocation analysis and I am capable of enumerating three of them.

ctext.p: The parameters should be selected in compliance with the research question or hypothesis. They offer the possibility to look at the object of study from different perspectives and therefore direct the researcher’s focus. It presents a certain challenge that one has to speculate on the nature of the phenomenon already when deciding on the respective parameters. They decisively affect the results of the analysis which is why you should consider readjusting them if necessary.
The variable parameters of a collocation analysis are for example the significance measure, span size and the minimum frequency or frequency threshold.

question.ctext: 2. I have the ability to explain the parameters lemma/word form/POS.

ctext.p: If one selects the parameter lemma, the infinitive of a word and its inflected forms are, so to say, treated as a package for the calculations. Within the collocation profile they are listed under the lemma.
When the word form shall be the basis of the collocation analysis, the inflected forms of a word are treated as individual collocates and listed separately.

Finally, in the case of the parameter POS the collocates of a node are pooled according to the parts of speech they are representing. In the collocation profile you will then find abbreviations or more precisely tags, which are based on the respective TagSet, e.g. for English on the Penn Treebank TagSet.

question.ctext: 3. I am capable of sketching the parameter span size out.

action.ctext: Collocations can also be discontinuous. Hence, when carrying out a collocation analysis you usually specify beforehand the co- or context which shall be included (mostly +/-5). Normally, sentence boundaries are disregarded, which means that collocations are calculated across sentence boundaries. However, this might be adjusted, depending on the software. Specifying the span size is a very important, but arbitrary decision. Again, the research question is decisive. The results should always be assessed critically and span size might have to be readjusted.

list.li: Change the parameter span size for a node chosen at will from -3/+3 to -5/+5 and then to -1/-1 and +1/+1. How do the results change?
Choose any node and switch between the settings of the parameter Word form/Lemma/POS. How do the results change?
Find out what you can learn about an arbitrarily selected word by means of a collocation analysis.

Compare the dictionary entry of a lexeme of your choice with its collocation profile. What differences and similarities (in terms of order of readings, examples for how the word is used, completeness...) do you find?
Carry out collocation analyses of political catchwords , e.g. of "freedom". Do you find differences between the parties? Explain and interpret them.

According to the Oxford Dictionary, "data" is originally a plural noun, which is nowadays treated as a mass noun as well. Hence, both forms "(the) data is" and "(the) data are" are used and widely accepted. Now, which expression is more common? Outline which approaches and search queries are feasible to answer this question.
